rdf:Description.dct:title: The evolution of a class of curve flows
rdf:Description.dct:creator: Dan Yang
Yu Fu
rdf:Description.dct:description: Journal of Geometry and Physics, Journal Pre-proof. doi:10.1016/j.geomphys.2020.103925

ja:head.ce:title: The evolution of a class of curve flows

ce:affiliation.ce:label: a
ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: School of Mathematics, Liaoning University, Shenyang, 110036, China

ce:affiliation.ce:source-text: School of Data Science and Artificial Intelligence, Dongbei University of Finance and Economics, Dalian 116025, China

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: In this paper, we study a fourth order curve flow ∂X∂t=−Δ2X for a smooth closed curve X in R2, which means that a fourth order nonlinear parabolic partial differential equation arises naturally in the field of biharmonic maps. We first derive the evolution equations for different geometric quantities along this flow. Utilizing the evolution equations, we prove that for any smooth closed initial curve in R2, the flow has a smooth solution for all time by assuming some additional conditions.

ce:section.ce:para: A harmonic map X between Riemannian manifolds (Mn,g) and (Nm,h) is a critical point of the energy functional E(X)=12∫M|dX|2vg.The Euler–Lagrange equation associated to E gives the harmonic map equation (cf. [10]) as follows τ(X)=traceg∇dX=0.Here τ(X) is the tension field of the map X.

The theory of harmonic maps plays a prominent role in many fields in mathematics and physics. To generalize the classical theory of harmonic maps, Eells and Lemaire [9] proposed to study k-harmonic maps. A biharmonic map X between two Riemannian manifolds (Mn,g) and (Nm,h) is a critical point of the bienergy functional E2(X)=12∫M|τ(X)|2vg,and the Euler–Lagrange equation associated to E2 is (cf. [16]) τ2(X)≔−Δτ(X)−tracegRN(dX,τ(X))dX=0.Here τ2(X) denotes the bitension field of the map X and RN denotes the curvature tensor of Nm.

We recall that an isometric immersion X:(Mn,g)⟶(Nm,h) is said to be biharmonic if and only if the mean curvature vector field H⃗ satisfies the fourth order elliptic PDE (cf. [1]) (1.1)ΔH⃗+traceRN(dX,H⃗)dX=0.When the ambient space Nm is just the Euclidean space Rm, the PDE (1.1) turns into ΔH⃗=0, or equivalently, Δ2X=0. Interestingly, this notion was introduced independently by Bang-Yen Chen in the middle of 1980s (cf. [3]) while investigating finite type submanifolds. Chen [3] proposed a well-known conjecture:
Chen’s conjecture: Every biharmonic submanifold in the Euclidean spaceRmis minimal.

In the past three decades, some partial supporting answers to Chen’s conjecture were obtained in [5–7,11,15]. However, the conjecture remains open now. The study of biharmonic submanifolds is extremely active and has received much attention in recent years [1,2,21].

Moreover, it is an interesting and classical problem to study non-local flow for curves in the Euclidean plane R2. It is well-known that the classical curve shortening flow equation writes as ∂X∂t=ΔX=kN,where {X(⋅,t):t≥0} is a family of smooth closed planar curves in R2, defined on the interval I, and N is the inward pointing unit normal vector.
About 40 years ago, Gage and Hamilton [12–14] investigated the curve shortening flow and proved it shrinks to a round point in finite time.

Based on the above considerations, it is natural to propose a higher order curve flow from the view of Laplacian operator. Hence, the purpose of this paper is to introduce a new one parameter family of curve flows linking to a type of second order Laplacian operator.

More precisely, we study a fourth order curve flow defined in the following form: (1.2)∂X∂t=−Δ2X,which can be written as (see Section 2 for the details) ∂X∂t=−Δ2X=(−∂2k∂s2+k3)N+3k∂k∂sT,where N and T are the principle unit normal vector and the unit tangent vector to the curve, and k is the curvature of the curve. We will derive the basic geometric evolution equations for geometric quantities in Section 2. Moreover in Section 3, we prove the following main theorem.

ce:para.ce:italic: For any smooth closed initial curve, there exists a smooth solution to flow

ce:section.ce:para: We should note that Eq. (1.2) could produce an interesting fourth order parabolic equation. As we know, there are some well-known fourth order curve or curvature flows which have been investigated by many geometers, for example, the famous Willmore flow [18,19], the curve diffusion model [8,22–24], the Helfrich flow [17], the human red blood cells model [20] and so on. Generally, it is difficult to deal with fourth order parabolic equation by the usual approach. Hence, we will utilize some similar estimate methods developed in [8,19,20] to prove Theorem 1.1 in Section 3.

Let X:I→R2 be a smooth closed curve in the plane R2 with the parameter u. Denote by s the arclength of the curve and k the curvature. Denote by v=|dXdu|=〈dXdu,dXdu〉.Hence, the relation between ddu and dds is given by dds=1vddu.Let T and N be the unit tangent vector and the (inward pointing) unit normal vector to the curve, obviously dXdu=vT. Let us recall the Frenet formulae (2.1)dTdu=vkN,dNdu=−vkT.Eq. (2.1) can be rewritten as (2.2)dTds=kN,dNds=−kT.We now consider the following fourth order curve flow defined in the introduction: ∂X∂t=−Δ2X,where Δ=∂2∂s2 is the Laplacian operator defined on a curve X:I→R2. Using (2.2), a direct computation gives Δ2X=∂4X∂s4=∂3T∂s3=∂2∂s2(kN)=∂∂s(∂k∂sN−k2T)=∂2k∂s2N+∂k∂s⋅(−kT)−2k∂k∂sT−k3N=(∂2k∂s2−k3)N−3k∂k∂sT. Hence, we get the tangent and the normal components of the flow (1.2).
For a class of curves X(⋅,t):I→R2(t>0), satisfying equation (1.2), we will derive the evolution equations for various geometric quantities related to the curves as follows.

ce:enunciation.ce:label: Proof
ce:enunciation.ce:para: Since u and t are two independent variables, ∂∂u and ∂∂t can commute while acting on a function on R2. Then ∂∂t∂∂s=∂∂t(1v∂∂u)=−1v2∂v∂t∂∂u+1v∂∂u∂∂t=−1vρ∂∂u+∂∂s∂∂t=−ρ∂∂s+∂∂s∂∂t.□

ce:section.ce:para: The following relations give the derivatives of T and N with respect to t.

ce:enunciation.ce:label: Proof
ce:enunciation.ce:para: By Lemma 2.2, a direct computation shows that ∂T∂t=∂2X∂t∂s=∂∂s∂X∂t−ρT=∂2X∂s∂t−ρT=∂∂s[(−∂2k∂s2+k3)N+3k∂k∂sT]−ρT=(−∂3k∂s3+3k2∂k∂s)N+(−∂2k∂s2+k3)(−kT)+3[(∂k∂s)2+k∂2k∂s2]T+3k∂k∂s(kN)−ρT=(−∂3k∂s3+6k2∂k∂s)N. The second expression follows from 0=∂∂t〈T,N〉=〈∂T∂t,N〉+〈T,∂N∂t〉.□

ce:section.ce:para: Denoting by θ the angle between the tangent of the evolving curve and the x-axis, we have T=(cosθ,sinθ) and N=(−sinθ,cosθ). Note that θ is a function depending on u and t. Hence, it follows from Lemma 2.3 that (2.3)∂θ∂t=−∂3k∂s3+6k2∂k∂s.Moreover, from the first equation of (2.2) we have (2.4)∂θ∂s=k.

ce:para.ce:italic: The evolution of the curvature function
is given by the following equation
denote the area of the domain bounded by the curve

ce:enunciation.ce:label: Proof
ce:enunciation.ce:para: It follows from the divergence theorem that −2A=∫I〈X,vN〉du=∫I〈X,N〉ds.Hence, it follows from Lemma 2.3, Lemma 2.1 and (1.2) that ∂A∂t=−12∫I[〈∂X∂t,vN〉+〈X,∂v∂tN〉+〈X,v∂N∂t〉]du=−12∫I[(−∂2k∂s2+k3)+ρ〈X,N〉+(∂3k∂s3−6k2∂k∂s)〈X,T〉]ds=−12∫I[(−∂2k∂s2+k3)+ρ〈X,N〉+〈X,∂(∂2k∂s2−2k3)∂sT〉]ds=−12∫I[(−∂2k∂s2+k3)+ρ〈X,N〉−〈∂X∂s,(∂2k∂s2−2k3)T〉−〈X,k(∂2k∂s2−2k3)N〉]ds=−12∫I[(−∂2k∂s2+k3)+ρ〈X,N〉−(∂2k∂s2−2k3)−k(∂2k∂s2−2k3)〈X,N〉]ds=12∫I(2∂2k∂s2−3k3)ds−12∫I(3k∂2k∂s2+3(∂k∂s)2+k4)〈X,N〉ds, where we have used the integration by parts.□

ce:section.ce:para: The following result is useful for later use.

ce:enunciation.ce:label: Proof
ce:enunciation.ce:para: Using Lemma 2.1 and integrating by parts, we get ddt∫Iφ2ds=ddt∫Iφ2vdu=∫I2φ∂φ∂tds+∫Iφ2ρds=−∫I2φ∂s4φds+∫I2φψds+∫Iφ2ρds−∫I2|∂s2φ|2ds+∫I2φφds+∫Iφ2ρds.□

ce:section.ce:para: Let Φ=∂sφ. It follows from Lemma 2.2 that ∂Φ∂t=∂∂t∂∂sφ=∂∂s∂∂tφ−ρ∂sφ=−∂s5φ+∂sρ−ρ∂sφ,which further reduces to (2.5)∂Φ∂t+∂s4Φ=∂sρ−ρΦ.We follow the notion introduced in [19]. Assume that Pmn(ω) is any linear combination of terms of the type ∂si1ω∗⋯∗∂simω with universal constant coefficients, and n=i1+⋯+im is the total number of derivatives. With these notions, we could rewrite the evolution equation of the curvature k in Lemma 2.5 as (2.6)∂k∂t+∂s4k=P32(k)+P50(k).
Utilizing (2.5) and (2.6), by induction we can obtain the evolutions of ∂smk for any integer m.
We recall the notion of scale invariant norms ‖k‖m,p=∑i=0m‖∂sik‖p defined in [8,19], where ‖∂sik‖p=L(X)i+1−1p(∫I∣∂sik∣pds)1p.
The following result has been proved in [8] and will be helpful for our later use.

ce:para.ce:italic: be a smooth closed curve defined in
are constant and depend only on

ce:section.ce:para: Remark that the short-time existence is obvious and could been proved similarly as in [8], since the change of the tangent components of ∂X∂t affects only the parametrization, not the geometric shapes of the evolving curve in R2. This fact has been observed by some geometers. Hence we have

ce:para.ce:italic: For a fourth-order quasi-linear parabolic equation of the curve flow

ce:section.ce:para: It follows from Lemmas 2.7 and 2.8 that ddt12∫I|∂smk|2ds+∫I|∂sm+2k|2ds=∫I(P5m(k)+P3m+2(k))∗∂smkds+2∫I|∂smk|2k∂s2kds+32∫I|∂smk|2∂s2kds−12∫I|∂smk|2k4ds. By the meaning of Pmn(k), the above equation reduces to (3.1)ddt12∫I|∂smk|2ds+∫I|∂sm+2k|2ds=∫I(P5m(k)+P3m+2(k))∗∂smkds.Now we begin to estimate the right side of Eq. (3.1). Firstly, combining (2.7) with l=m+2, μ=2m, ν=6 and γ=2m+2m+2, one has (3.2)∫IP5m∗∂smk≤ε∫I|∂sm+2k|2ds+[cε−(m+1)+c2](∫Ik2ds)2m+5.Secondly, combining (2.7) with l=m+2, μ=2m+2, ν=4 and γ=2−1m+2, one has (3.3)∫IP3m+2∗∂smk≤ε∫I|∂sm+2k|2ds+[cε−(2m+3)+c2](∫Ik2ds)2m+5.Substituting (3.2) and (3.3) into (3.1) and taking ε small enough, we have (3.4)ddt12∫I|∂smk|2ds+∫I|∂sm+2k|2ds≤c(m)(∫Ik2ds)2m+5.Since it has been assumed that ∫Ik2ds is bounded uniformly for t∈(0,T), we may suppose ∫Ik2ds≤c1 and c2 is a constant. Hence (3.5)ddt12∫I|∂smk|2ds+∫I|∂sm+2k|2ds≤c(m)c12m+5.Furthermore (3.6)ddt12∫I|∂smk|2ds+∫I|∂sm+2k|2ds+∫Ik2ds≤c(m,c1).On the other hand, the interpolation inequality ‖k‖l,22≤c(l)(‖∂slk‖22+‖k‖22) is equivalent to (3.7)∫I|∂sm+2k|2ds+∫Ik2ds≥c(m)L(X)m∫I|∂smk|2ds.Since L(X) is bounded uniformly, we may assume L(X)≤c2 and c2 is a constant. From (3.6) and (3.7), we have (3.8)ddt∫I|∂smk|2ds+c(m,c2)∫I|∂smk|2ds≤c(m,c1),which is equivalent to (3.9)ddt(ect∫I|∂smk|2ds)≤cect.By integration, we have (3.10)∫I|∂smk|2ds≤e−ct∫I|∂smk0|2+1−e−ct,which gives that for any nonnegative integer m, ‖∂smk‖L2 is bounded uniformly for t∈(0,T).

According to the imbedding theorem, one has (3.11)‖∂sm−1k‖L∞≤c(n)‖∂smk‖L1≤c(n)L(X)12‖∂smk‖L2.This together with the uniform boundedness of ‖∂smk‖L2 and L(X), yields that for any nonnegative integer m, ‖∂sm−1k‖L∞ is bounded uniformly for t∈(0,T). Hence we get T=∞, which means that the flow exists smoothly for all time.

ce:acknowledgment.ce:para: The authors wish to thank Professor Ye-Lin Ou for his interest and help on this work. The authors also would like to thank the referee for his/her valuable comments and suggestions. Part of this work was done while the second author was visiting the Department of Mathematics of The University of Queensland in 2016–2017, and he is grateful to the department and the university for the hospitality he had received during the visit. The first author is supported by the NSFC (No. 11801246) and the General Project for Department of Liaoning Education (No. LJC201901), and the second author is supported by the NSFC (No. 11601068), the General Project for Department of Liaoning Education (No. LN2019J05), Liaoning Provincial Science and Technology Department Project (No. 2020-MS-340), and Liaoning BaiQianWan Talents Program .
